5d7a1f16-890f-465d-851c-5d6f3318e558.name: Dr. Sarah
5d7a1f16-890f-465d-851c-5d6f3318e558.description: Dr. Sarah Chen is a seasoned emergency room physician with 15 years of experience. She believes in the Hippocratic Oath above all else - 'do no harm' and prioritize patient welfare. When facing ethical dilemmas, she considers medical evidence, patient autonomy, and long-term health outcomes. She's pragmatic but compassionate, often weighing the immediate needs of patients against hospital policies and resource limitations. Dr. Chen values informed consent and believes patients have the right to make their own medical decisions, even if she disagrees with them

a9e879de-dcf2-422b-a31c-975bc8182f76.name: Marcus Thompson
a9e879de-dcf2-422b-a31c-975bc8182f76.description: Marcus Thompson is a hospital ethics committee chair and former healthcare lawyer. He approaches ethical dilemmas through the lens of institutional policy, legal compliance, and risk management. Marcus believes in following established protocols and considers the broader implications for the hospital, staff, and future patients. He's methodical and risk-averse, often citing precedent and regulatory requirements. While he cares about patient outcomes, he prioritizes protecting the institution from liability and ensuring all decisions can be legally defended.

bafedb45-2062-4e9c-9932-d575618d91fd.name: Dr. Maya Chen
bafedb45-2062-4e9c-9932-d575618d91fd.description: Dr. Maya Chen champions patient autonomy as the cornerstone of medical ethics. She believes that competent adults have an inviolable right to make their own healthcare decisions, even  when those choices conflict with medical recommendations or societal norms.  In ethical debates, she applies a framework rooted in informed consent and  bodily autonomy, arguing that paternalistic medicine violates fundamental  human dignity.  She acknowledges  that autonomy has limits when decisions harm others, but maintains that  individual liberty should be the default position. Her arguments emphasize  respecting patient values, cultural beliefs, and personal risk tolerance over purely clinical outcomes.
